bestBHT.bht: Receiving salvation is the ultimate culmination and completion of one's faith. Believers presently receive a taste of salvation, even though its full revelation is yet to come. It is a present reality that the soul of the believer is already saved, serving as evidence of the ongoing receiving of salvation. This spiritual and eternal salvation, obtained through faith and secured by the precious sacrifice of Christ, surpasses the temporal and fleeting nature of earthly life. Its immeasurable worth transcends all worldly pursuits and offers a hope that is beyond compare.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the end of your faith... its crowning consummation, finally completed 'salvation'".
believers even now 'receive salvation,' though its full 'revelation' is future".
the soul of the believer is saved already: an additional proof that 'receiving . . . salvation' is here a thing present".
Albert Barnes: The result or object of your faith; that is, what your faith is designed and adapted to secure."
They even now had such peace and joy in believing, that it furnished undoubted evidence that they would be saved."
The condition of one who is a true Christian here is so secure that it may even now be called salvation.
John Calvin: He indirectly intimates that the loss of all other things is to be deemed as nothing, provided our souls be saved.
We learn from the Apostle’s words, that salvation is not otherwise obtained than by faith; and we know that faith leans on the sole promise of gratuitous adoption.
For there is an implied comparison between [eternal salvation] and the mortal and fading life which belongs to the body.
Archibald T. Robertson: Receiving... to get what is promised.
The conclusion, the culmination of faith.
John Gill: Salvation intends spiritual and eternal salvation; that which God appointed his people to from all eternity, which is obtained by Christ, applied by the Spirit, and will be fully enjoyed in heaven.
This is the salvation 'of souls': which are of more worth than a world; and the redemption of which is precious, and requires a great price.

Salvation rather takes place in the soul than in the body, which is exposed to various labours, afflictions, and diseases; but the chief design of the phrase is, to distinguish this salvation from a corporeal and temporal one.
John Wesley: Salvation — From all sin into all holiness, which is the qualification for, the forerunner and pledge of, eternal salvation.

bhtAttempts.bht: Receiving salvation is the ultimate culmination and completion of one's faith. Believers presently receive a taste of salvation, even though its full revelation is yet to come. It is a present reality that the soul of the believer is already saved, serving as evidence that the receiving of salvation is happening in the here and now. This salvation is not simply a future hope, but a current experience of the promised redemption. It is a spiritual and eternal salvation, obtained through faith and secured by the precious sacrifice of Christ. This salvation is far more valuable than anything the world can offer and transcends the temporal and fleeting nature of earthly life.

Receiving salvation is the culmination of faith, its crowning completion, and the final salvation. Believers already possess the salvation of their souls, a present reality that serves as proof of their receiving of salvation. It is not merely a future hope, but a current experience of promised redemption. This spiritual and eternal salvation is obtained through faith and is of utmost worth, surpassing the fleeting nature of earthly life. Its value is immeasurable and requires the great price of Christ's sacrifice.

It is not merely a future hope, but a current experience of promised redemption. This spiritual and eternal salvation is obtained through faith and exceeds the value of earthly life. Its worth is immeasurable and dependent on Christ's sacrifice.
